Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Haven’t heard from you in a while. Everything okay?” I glance at the clock—3:55 p.m. The weekly team meeting starts in five minutes. I know the meeting will be recorded, but my manager always appreciates when everyone joins live and contributes. Still, I can almost hear my mom’s voice, tinged with worry, hoping for a quick call or at least a thoughtful reply. I type out a hasty “All good, just busy!” but hesitate before sending it. It feels too brief, almost dismissive. At the same time, my laptop pings with a calendar reminder. I picture my teammates’ faces in the little video boxes, waiting for updates, expecting me to be present and engaged. My heart pounds as I sit at the crossroads—do I call my mom and risk missing the meeting, or do I join the meeting and leave my mom waiting, her concern growing? The weight of both expectations presses down on me, and I can’t shake the feeling that, no matter what I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
